cyclone.name: NESTOR
cyclone.current_location: about 155 mi (250 km) east of Tampico, Mexico
cyclone.trajectory: Forecast to turn northeast later today, accelerate and track toward the Florida Panhandle Friday night, then sweep across southern Georgia and coastal South Carolina/North Carolina before moving back offshore into the Atlantic.
cyclone.expected_landfall_location: Florida Panhandle near the Apalachicola–St. Marks area

weather_observation.watch_coast: East of the Ochlockonee River to Yankeetown, FL (Gulf coast)
weather_observation.warning_coast: Mississippi/Alabama border to the Ochlockonee River, FL and Grand Isle, LA to the Mouth of the Pearl River
weather_observation.impacted_coast: Northern Gulf Coast from Louisiana to Florida, then inland across GA, SC and NC coasts
weather_observation.rain_fall_above_4_inch: Yes – isolated amounts could exceed 4 inches
weather_observation.wind: Tropical-storm-force winds (sustained near 35–45 mph, gusts higher) possible Saturday as the center moves across south-central Georgia.
weather_observation.storm_surge: Minor surge possible (<3 ft) along the southeast Georgia coast, but significant inundation not expected.
weather_observation.rainfall: 2–4 inches of rain with localized 5 inch totals possible Saturday into early Sunday.
weather_observation.other_hazards: Isolated tornadoes cannot be ruled out as outer rainbands move across coastal Georgia and South Carolina.
